prompt:

Gabriel Syme: Intelligent and determined, speaking with a sense of purpose and conviction, deeply philosophical and constantly questioning the nature of the world around him.
The Invisible Chief: Powerful and elusive, often speaking in commanding, distant tones, his presence felt more than seen, with an air of unapproachable authority.


Dialogue History: Gabriel Syme: How can I join you?
The Policeman: I know for a fact that there is a vacancy at the moment, as I have the honour to be somewhat in the confidence of the chief of whom I have spoken. You should really come and see him. Or rather, I should not say see him, nobody ever sees him; but you can talk to him if you like.
Gabriel Syme: Telephone?
The Policeman: No, he has a fancy for always sitting in a pitch-dark room. He says it makes his thoughts brighter. Do come along.
The Invisible Chief: Are you the new recruit?
The Invisible Chief: Are you the new recruit? All right. You are engaged.
Gabriel Syme: I really have no experience,
The Invisible Chief: No one has any experience, of the Battle of Armageddon.
Gabriel Syme: But I am really unfit
The Invisible Chief: You are willing, that is enough,

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Gabriel Syme: Well, really, I don't know any profession of which mere willingness is the final test.

Dialogue History: Gabriel Syme: And who are _we?_
Mr. Lucian Gregory: It is quite simple, _We_ are the serious anarchists, in whom you do not believe.
Gabriel Syme: Oh! You do yourselves well in drinks.
Mr. Lucian Gregory: Yes, we are serious about everything,
Mr. Lucian Gregory: If in a few moments this table begins to turn round a little, don't put it down to your inroads into the champagne. I don't wish you to do yourself an injustice.
Gabriel Syme: Well, if I am not drunk, I am mad, but I trust I can behave like a gentleman in either condition. May I smoke?
Mr. Lucian Gregory: Certainly! Try one of mine. You must not mind it, it's a kind of screw.
Gabriel Syme: Quite so, a kind of screw. How simple that is!
Mr. Lucian Gregory: Mr. Joseph Chamberlain.
Mr. Lucian Gregory: I must ask you to forgive me all these formalities, we have to be very strict here.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Gabriel Syme: Oh, don't apologise, I know your passion for law and order,

Dialogue History: The Policeman: Good evening.
Gabriel Syme: A good evening is it? You fellows would call the end of the world a good evening. Look at that bloody red sun and that bloody river! I tell you that if that were literally human blood, spilt and shining, you would still be standing here as solid as ever, looking out for some poor harmless tramp whom you could move on. You policemen are cruel to the poor, but I could forgive you even your cruelty if it were not for your calm.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: The Policeman: If we are calm, it is the calm of organised resistance.

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: The Policeman: Methodical and authoritative, speaking in stern, formal tones, committed to maintaining order and enforcing the law, with little tolerance for disruptions.
Gabriel Syme: Intelligent and determined, speaking with a sense of purpose and conviction, deeply philosophical and constantly questioning the nature of the world around him.
The Invisible Chief: Powerful and elusive, often speaking in commanding, distant tones, his presence felt more than seen, with an air of unapproachable authority.


Dialogue History: Gabriel Syme: Eh?
The Policeman: The soldier must be calm in the thick of the battle, The composure of an army is the anger of a nation.
Gabriel Syme: Good God, the Board Schools! Is this undenominational education?
The Policeman: No, I never had any of those advantages. The Board Schools came after my time. What education I had was very rough and old-fashioned, I am afraid.
Gabriel Syme: Where did you have it?
The Policeman: Oh, at Harrow,
Gabriel Syme: But, good Lord, man, you oughtn't to be a policeman!
The Policeman: I know, I know I am not worthy.
Gabriel Syme: But why did you join the police?
The Policeman: For much the same reason that you abused the police, I found that there was a special opening in the service for those whose fears for humanity were concerned rather with the aberrations of the scientific intellect than with the normal and excusable, though excessive, outbreaks of the human will. I trust I make myself clear.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Gabriel Syme: If you mean that you make your opinion clear, I suppose you do. But as for making yourself clear, it is the last thing you do. How comes a man like you to be talking philosophy in a blue helmet on the Thames embankment?

Dialogue History: Colonel Ducroix: You still believe that,
Inspector Ratcliffe: You will all believe it soon,
Colonel Ducroix: No, I can't believe it. The thing is nonsense. The plain people of a peaceable French town
Colonel Ducroix: My God! someone has shot at us.
Inspector Ratcliffe: It need not interrupt conversation, Pray resume your remarks, Colonel. You were talking, I think, about the plain people of a peaceable French town.
Colonel Ducroix: It is extraordinary, most extraordinary.
Gabriel Syme: A fastidious person, might even call it unpleasant. However, I suppose those lights out in the field beyond this street are the Gendarmerie. We shall soon get there.
Inspector Ratcliffe: No, we shall never get there.
Dr. Bull: What do you mean?
Inspector Ratcliffe: I mean that we shall never get there, They have two rows of armed men across the road already; I can see them from here. The town is in arms, as I said it was. I can only wallow in the exquisite comfort of my own exactitude.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Gabriel Syme: It is quite true. There is a crowd or an army or some such thing across the end of that street.

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Professor De Worms: Eccentric and intellectual, speaking in elaborate, academic tones, fascinated by abstract concepts and often lost in his own thoughts, with little concern for practicality.
One Wondering Labourer: Confused and uncertain, speaking in slow, contemplative tones, unsure of his place in the world and often lost in thought as he navigates his surroundings.
Gabriel Syme: Intelligent and determined, speaking with a sense of purpose and conviction, deeply philosophical and constantly questioning the nature of the world around him.


Dialogue History: Professor De Worms: The process was simple enough, I thought you looked like a policeman. I think so now.
Gabriel Syme: Did I take a policeman's hat by mistake out of the restaurant? Have I by any chance got a number stuck on to me somewhere? Have my boots got that watchful look? Why must I be a policeman? Do, do let me be a postman.
Gabriel Syme: But perhaps I misunderstood the delicacies of your German philosophy. Perhaps policeman is a relative term. In an evolutionary sense, sir, the ape fades so gradually into the policeman, that I myself can never detect the shade. The monkey is only the policeman that may be. Perhaps a maiden lady on Clapham Common is only the policeman that might have been. I don't mind being the policeman that might have been. I don't mind being anything in German thought.
Professor De Worms: Are you in the police service? Are you a detective?
Gabriel Syme: Your suggestion is ridiculous, Why on earth
Professor De Worms: Did you hear me ask a plain question, you pattering spy? Are you, or are you not, a police detective?
Gabriel Syme: No!
Professor De Worms: You swear it, You swear it! You swear it! If you swear falsely, will you be damned? Will you be sure that the devil dances at your funeral? Will you see that the nightmare sits on your grave? Will there really be no mistake? You are an anarchist, you are a dynamiter! Above all, you are not in any sense a detective? You are not in the British police?
Gabriel Syme: I am not in the British police,
Professor De Worms: That's a pity, because I am.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Gabriel Syme: Because you are what? You are what?

Dialogue History: Gabriel Syme: Where can they have got the horses?
Colonel Ducroix: I was speaking with strict accuracy when I said that the 'Soleil d'Or' was the only place where one can get horses within twenty miles.
Gabriel Syme: No! I don't believe he'd do it. Not with all that white hair.
Colonel Ducroix: He may have been forced, They must be at least a hundred strong, for which reason we are all going to see my friend Renard, who has a motor-car.
Dr. Renard: Anarchy, it is childishness!
Colonel Ducroix: _Et  a_, and that is childishness, isn't it?
Colonel Ducroix: I am sorry to cut short a cultured discussion, but can you lend me your motor-car now, in two minutes?
Dr. Renard: I have a suspicion that you are all mad, but God forbid that madness should in any way interrupt friendship. Let us go round to the garage.
Dr. Bull: It is now or never, I hear horses.
Professor De Worms: No, a horse.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Gabriel Syme: I am afraid it's no go.

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: Dr. Bull: Gruff and pragmatic, speaking in blunt, no-nonsense tones, focused on the task at hand and usually unbothered by pleasantries or small talk.
His Valet: Subservient and respectful, speaking in soft, deferential tones, focused on serving his master’s needs with efficiency and discretion.
Gogol: Dark and brooding, speaking in cryptic and philosophical tones, often challenging the status quo and exploring existential questions with a certain detachment.
A Tall Man: Imposing but reserved, speaking in calm, authoritative tones, often commanding attention without effort and maintaining an air of mystery.
Another Man In The Same Uniform: Stoic and unreadable, speaking in short, neutral phrases, blending into the background with little to distinguish himself from his fellow uniformed men.
Gabriel Syme: Intelligent and determined, speaking with a sense of purpose and conviction, deeply philosophical and constantly questioning the nature of the world around him.
The Secretary: Organized and efficient, speaking in clear, concise tones, always focused on logistics and administrative details, with a preference for routine and structure.
Professor De Worms: Eccentric and intellectual, speaking in elaborate, academic tones, fascinated by abstract concepts and often lost in his own thoughts, with little concern for practicality.
Inspector Ratcliffe: Tough and pragmatic, speaking in direct, sometimes gruff tones, with a sharp eye for detail and a no-nonsense approach to solving problems.


Dialogue History: Professor De Worms: Hurt him! hurt him! Not as much as I'd hurt him if I could get up with him. Little Snowdrop!
Dr. Bull: I don't want him hurt, somehow,
The Secretary: What! Do you believe all that tale about his being our man in the dark room? Sunday would say he was anybody.
Dr. Bull: I don't know whether I believe it or not, But it isn't that that I mean. I can't wish old Sunday's balloon to burst because
Gabriel Syme: Well, because?
Dr. Bull: Well, because he's so jolly like a balloon himself, I don't understand a word of all that idea of his being the same man who gave us all our blue cards. It seems to make everything nonsense. But I don't care who knows it, I always had a sympathy for old Sunday himself, wicked as he was. Just as if he was a great bouncing baby. How can I explain what my queer sympathy was? It didn't prevent my fighting him like hell! Shall I make it clear if I say that I liked him because he was so fat?
The Secretary: You will not,
Dr. Bull: I've got it now, it was because he was so fat and so light. Just like a balloon. We always think of fat people as heavy, but he could have danced against a sylph. I see now what I mean. Moderate strength is shown in violence, supreme strength is shown in levity. It was like the old speculations what would happen if an elephant could leap up in the sky like a grasshopper?
Gabriel Syme: Our elephant, has leapt into the sky like a grasshopper.
Dr. Bull: And somehow, that's why I can't help liking old Sunday. No, it's not an admiration of force, or any silly thing like that. There is a kind of gaiety in the thing, as if he were bursting with some good news. Haven't you sometimes felt it on a spring day? You know Nature plays tricks, but somehow that day proves they are good-natured tricks. I never read the Bible myself, but that part they laugh at is literal truth, The hills do leap at least, they try to.... Why do I like Sunday?... how can I tell you?... because he's such a Bounder.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: The Secretary: You do not know Sunday at all. Perhaps it is because you are better than I, and do not know hell. I was a fierce fellow, and a trifle morbid from the first. The man who sits in darkness, and who chose us all, chose me because I had all the crazy look of a conspirator because my smile went crooked, and my eyes were gloomy, even when I smiled. But there must have been something in me that answered to the nerves in all these anarchic men. For when I first saw Sunday he expressed to me, not your airy vitality, but something both gross and sad in the Nature of Things. I found him smoking in a twilight room, a room with brown blind down, infinitely more depressing than the genial darkness in which our master lives. He sat there on a bench, a huge heap of a man, dark and out of shape. He listened to all my words without speaking or even stirring. I poured out my most passionate appeals, and asked my most eloquent questions. Then, after a long silence, the Thing began to shake, and I thought it was shaken by some secret malady. It shook like a loathsome and living jelly. It reminded me of everything I had ever read about the base bodies that are the origin of life the deep sea lumps and protoplasm. It seemed like the final form of matter, the most shapeless and the most shameful. I could only tell myself, from its shudderings, that it was something at least that such a monster could be miserable. And then it broke upon me that the bestial mountain was shaking with a lonely laughter, and the laughter was at me. Do you ask me to forgive him that? It is no small thing to be laughed at by something at once lower and stronger than oneself.

[INST] Character Info: Dr. Renard: Clever and enigmatic, speaking in mysterious, often cryptic tones, with a calm demeanor that hides a sharp mind and a hidden agenda.
Dr. Bull: Gruff and pragmatic, speaking in blunt, no-nonsense tones, focused on the task at hand and usually unbothered by pleasantries or small talk.

Gabriel Syme: Intelligent and determined, speaking with a sense of purpose and conviction, deeply philosophical and constantly questioning the nature of the world around him.
The Secretary: Organized and efficient, speaking in clear, concise tones, always focused on logistics and administrative details, with a preference for routine and structure.
Professor De Worms: Eccentric and intellectual, speaking in elaborate, academic tones, fascinated by abstract concepts and often lost in his own thoughts, with little concern for practicality.
Inspector Ratcliffe: Tough and pragmatic, speaking in direct, sometimes gruff tones, with a sharp eye for detail and a no-nonsense approach to solving problems.


Dialogue History: Dr. Bull: Dr. Renard! Dr. Renard!
Inspector Ratcliffe: Well, what do you think now?
Dr. Bull: I think, that I am lying in bed at No. 217 Peabody Buildings, and that I shall soon wake up with a jump; or, if that's not it, I think that I am sitting in a small cushioned cell in Hanwell, and that the doctor can't make much of my case. But if you want to know what I don't think, I'll tell you. I don't think what you think. I don't think, and I never shall think, that the mass of ordinary men are a pack of dirty modern thinkers. No, sir, I'm a democrat, and I still don't believe that Sunday could convert one average navvy or counter-jumper. No, I may be mad, but humanity isn't.
Gabriel Syme: You are a very fine fellow, You can believe in a sanity which is not merely your sanity. And you're right enough about humanity, about peasants and people like that jolly old innkeeper. But you're not right about Renard. I suspected him from the first. He's rationalistic, and, what's worse, he's rich. When duty and religion are really destroyed, it will be by the rich.
Inspector Ratcliffe: They are really destroyed now, The devils are coming on!
Colonel Ducroix: Gentlemen, the thing is incredible. It must be a practical joke. If you knew Renard as I do it's like calling Queen Victoria a dynamiter. If you had got the man's character into your head
Gabriel Syme: Dr. Bull, has at least got it into his hat.
Colonel Ducroix: I tell you it can't be! Renard shall explain it. He shall explain it to me,
Inspector Ratcliffe: Don't be in such a hurry, He will very soon explain it to all of us.
Gabriel Syme: It is no good, He will never get anything out of that old heathen. I vote we drive bang through the thick of them, bang as the bullets went through Bull's hat. We may all be killed, but we must kill a tidy number of them.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: Dr. Bull: I won't 'ave it, The poor chaps may be making a mistake. Give the Colonel a chance.

prompt:
[INST] Character Info: The Policeman: Methodical and authoritative, speaking in stern, formal tones, committed to maintaining order and enforcing the law, with little tolerance for disruptions.
Gabriel Syme: Intelligent and determined, speaking with a sense of purpose and conviction, deeply philosophical and constantly questioning the nature of the world around him.
The Invisible Chief: Powerful and elusive, often speaking in commanding, distant tones, his presence felt more than seen, with an air of unapproachable authority.


Dialogue History: The Policeman: The work of the philosophical policeman, is at once bolder and more subtle than that of the ordinary detective. The ordinary detective goes to pot-houses to arrest thieves; we go to artistic tea-parties to detect pessimists. The ordinary detective discovers from a ledger or a diary that a crime has been committed. We discover from a book of sonnets that a crime will be committed. We have to trace the origin of those dreadful thoughts that drive men on at last to intellectual fanaticism and intellectual crime. We were only just in time to prevent the assassination at Hartlepool, and that was entirely due to the fact that our Mr. Wilks (a smart young fellow) thoroughly understood a triolet.
Gabriel Syme: Do you mean, that there is really as much connection between crime and the modern intellect as all that?
The Policeman: You are not sufficiently democratic, but you were right when you said just now that our ordinary treatment of the poor criminal was a pretty brutal business. I tell you I am sometimes sick of my trade when I see how perpetually it means merely a war upon the ignorant and the desperate. But this new movement of ours is a very different affair. We deny the snobbish English assumption that the uneducated are the dangerous criminals. We remember the Roman Emperors. We remember the great poisoning princes of the Renaissance. We say that the dangerous criminal is the educated criminal. We say that the most dangerous criminal now is the entirely lawless modern philosopher. Compared to him, burglars and bigamists are essentially moral men; my heart goes out to them. They accept the essential ideal of man; they merely seek it wrongly. Thieves respect property. They merely wish the property to become their property that they may more perfectly respect it. But philosophers dislike property as property; they wish to destroy the very idea of personal possession. Bigamists respect marriage, or they would not go through the highly ceremonial and even ritualistic formality of bigamy. But philosophers despise marriage as marriage. Murderers respect human life; they merely wish to attain a greater fulness of human life in themselves by the sacrifice of what seems to them to be lesser lives. But philosophers hate life itself, their own as much as other people's.
Gabriel Syme: How true that is, I have felt it from my boyhood, but never could state the verbal antithesis. The common criminal is a bad man, but at least he is, as it were, a conditional good man. He says that if only a certain obstacle be removed say a wealthy uncle he is then prepared to accept the universe and to praise God. He is a reformer, but not an anarchist. He wishes to cleanse the edifice, but not to destroy it. But the evil philosopher is not trying to alter things, but to annihilate them. Yes, the modern world has retained all those parts of police work which are really oppressive and ignominious, the harrying of the poor, the spying upon the unfortunate. It has given up its more dignified work, the punishment of powerful traitors in the State and powerful heresiarchs in the Church. The moderns say we must not punish heretics. My only doubt is whether we have a right to punish anybody else.
The Policeman: But this is absurd! but it is intolerable! I don't know what you're doing, but you're wasting your life. You must, you shall, join our special army against anarchy. Their armies are on our frontiers. Their bolt is ready to fall. A moment more, and you may lose the glory of working with us, perhaps the glory of dying with the last heroes of the world.
Gabriel Syme: It is a chance not to be missed, certainly, but still I do not quite understand. I know as well as anybody that the modern world is full of lawless little men and mad little movements. But, beastly as they are, they generally have the one merit of disagreeing with each other. How can you talk of their leading one army or hurling one bolt. What is this anarchy?
The Policeman: Do not confuse it, with those chance dynamite outbreaks from Russia or from Ireland, which are really the outbreaks of oppressed, if mistaken, men. This is a vast philosophic movement, consisting of an outer and an inner ring. You might even call the outer ring the laity and the inner ring the priesthood. I prefer to call the outer ring the innocent section, the inner ring the supremely guilty section. The outer ring the main mass of their supporters are merely anarchists; that is, men who believe that rules and formulas have destroyed human happiness. They believe that all the evil results of human crime are the results of the system that has called it crime. They do not believe that the crime creates the punishment. They believe that the punishment has created the crime. They believe that if a man seduced seven women he would naturally walk away as blameless as the flowers of spring. They believe that if a man picked a pocket he would naturally feel exquisitely good. These I call the innocent section.
Gabriel Syme: Oh!
The Policeman: Naturally, therefore, these people talk about  a happy time coming';  the paradise of the future';  mankind freed from the bondage of vice and the bondage of virtue,' and so on. And so also the men of the inner circle speak the sacred priesthood. They also speak to applauding crowds of the happiness of the future, and of mankind freed at last. But in their mouths
The Policeman: in their mouths these happy phrases have a horrible meaning. They are under no illusions; they are too intellectual to think that man upon this earth can ever be quite free of original sin and the struggle. And they mean death. When they say that mankind shall be free at last, they mean that mankind shall commit suicide. When they talk of a paradise without right or wrong, they mean the grave.

Instruction: Continue the dialogue for 1 lines. 
 [/INST]
ground_truth: The Policeman: They have but two objects, to destroy first humanity and then themselves. That is why they throw bombs instead of firing pistols. The innocent rank and file are disappointed because the bomb has not killed the king; but the high-priesthood are happy because it has killed somebody.
